awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Structure and depth extent of lithospheric shear zones surrounding continental transform faults
awd_abstract_narration:
At continental transform faults such as the San Andreas, one tectonic plate slides horizontally relative to its neighbor. Because such faults lie on land and often in populated areas, the resulting earthquakes dramatically impact local populations. It remains debated how plates deform beneath the shallow (~10 km), top layer where earthquakes are generated. At larger depths, underlying rocks transition from brittle to ductile deformation. But whether the shear zone underneath the fault remains narrow for tens of km, or whether deformation widens right away is not clear. These different scenarios affect how faults are loaded, and have significant implications for seismic hazard assessment. Here, the team uses existing seismic records to investigate six major continental transform faults. Deformed rocks often exhibit crystal preferred orientations, fabrics, that can be detected with seismic waves. This is because rock fabrics affect the wave velocity which then depends on the propagation direction. By analyzing the anisotropy of seismic waves passing underneath the fault zones, the researchers probe the geometry and extent of rocks deformation. They also use geodynamic modeling constrained by geological observations; for given fault geometries and deformation properties, they predict seismic anisotropy features underneath the faults. By comparing observations and predictions, the team unravels the deformation behavior of continental transform faults. The project fosters an international collaboration with Australia and Switzerland. It provides support and training to a female graduate student, and outreach toward undergraduates and K12 students - notably from group underrepresented in Sciences - and the public.  
 
The team uses data from existing deployments crossing six continental transform faults (San Andreas, North Anatolian, Denali, New Zealand Alpine, Altyn Tagh/Kunlun, and Dead Sea). It conducts full-waveform 2-D and 3-D modeling of teleseismic shear wave splitting, as well as anisotropic receiver function analysis. The goal is to image the shear zone and broader deformation field surrounding each transform fault. The selected faults represent transforms of different ages and maturity. Existing splitting observations show systematic contrasts between faults. Combining high-resolution shear zone imaging and geodynamic modeling, the researchers investigate the degree of strain localization in the lithosphere and the shear zone geometry. They also study the possible roles of mechanical anisotropy and inherited fabrics. This project is a critical step toward establishing a model for continental lithospheric transforms and better assessing the corresponding earthquake hazards.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of Texas Institute for Geophysics

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: STUDIES OF THE EARTH'S DEEP INTERIOR

por.por_cntn:
Plate tectonics is part of mantle convection and the ever-evolving tectonic processes accommodating heat loss on our planet are reflected in the million-year timescale creation and recycling of oceanic plates, as well as generational and ~1000-year timescale evolution of fault systems hosting earthquakes at plate boundaries. This grant supported a range of geodynamic modeling and analysis of observational data of a key constraint on all these processes from seismic anisotropy, across spatial scales, but with focus on the evolution of fault zones.

Seismic anisotropy refers to the observation that earthquake generated waves are observed to travel at different speeds in different directions or if their vibrations are polarized differently. In the crust, such effects can be caused by shape preferred orientation of different wave speed lithologies, and in the mantle most of the anisotropy arises from crystallographic preferred orientation of intrinsically anisotropic crystals under mantle flow.  

Among the efforts supported by this grant was an analysis of a comprehensive range of crustal stress and strain-rate indicators from seismology, geodesy, and geology for southern California and its fault systems. Results indicate that that lithospheric fabric, developed during Farallon subduction and subsequent extension, has not been completely reset by present-day transform motion and may influence the current deformation behavior, including fault loading stresses. This provides a new perspective on the timescales of deformation memory and lithosphere-asthenosphere interactions.

We also analyzed azimuthal anisotropy for the Juan de Fuca ‐ Gorda plates from inversion of a new Rayleigh wave dataset. In the oceanic lithosphere, most anisotropy patterns reflect the kinematics of plate formation, as approximated from seafloor‐age‐based paleo‐spreading, except in this case for regions close to propagator wakes and near plate boundaries. In the asthenosphere, the fast propagation orientations align with convective shear as inferred from the NUVEL1A plate motion model, which is indicative of a ∼3 Myr average, rather than with the more recent, ∼0.8 Myr, motions inferred from MORVEL. Regional anisotropy of this young plate system thus records convection like older plates such as the Pacific. On smaller scales, anisotropy imaging provides insights into dynamics of plate generation and can further elucidate plate reorganizations and changes in boundary loading.

From the ongoing projects, we expect a comparative study analysis anisotropy strength and patterns for the San Andreas and North Anatolia fault system to be published in 2025, for example. Such analysis will speak to the downward continuation of shear deformation underneath different geological age faults. This will provide crucial constraints for our understanding of how strain is localized in continental transform faults and how such damage evolves over time. Such an integrative mechanical process understanding will be relevant for a range of issues, including to help interpret shifting patterns of seismicity and fault slip rates in fault systems such as in the western United States.

Seven peer-reviewed papers and several projects were supported by this grant, with five more to be submitted over the next months. The grant also supported initial training of a PhD student and two post-doctoral scholars, as well as mentoring and interactions with three additional post-doctoral scholars. Our software developments are openly shared on GitHub, including Python scripts and Jupyter notebooks that use our research software for teaching purposes, now routinely for undergraduate instruction at UT Austin.

 


Last Modified: 12/02/2024
Modified by: Thorsten W Becker
